Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A customer urgently needs their delivery by the promised time window, such as groceries for dinner
Story: I was just about to leave for my delivery route when I noticed the trash bins lined up along the curb. As a neighbor, I always try to be considerate—our building has limited space, and we’re supposed to avoid putting out half-full bins to keep the sidewalk clear. But today, my delivery schedule is packed, and one of my stops is for Mrs. Kim, who called earlier, desperate for her groceries before dinner. If I wait until the bins are full, I’ll miss my delivery window and let her down. If I leave now, the bins might not get picked up, and my neighbors will be annoyed at the mess and wasted space. I can already hear Mr. Patel’s complaints about blocking the walkway. My phone buzzes with a reminder: “Deliver by 5:30 PM.” I stand there, keys in hand, torn between being the reliable neighbor who respects our shared space and the delivery person who never misses a deadline. The pressure from both sides tightens in my chest as I weigh what to do next.
